paragraphs.text: %md # xtra tutorial: Working with Oracle Data Visualization Desktop and Hive This tutorial was built for BDCS-CE version 17.3.5-20 as part of the New Data Lake User Journey: here. Questions and feedback about the tutorial: Note: This tutorial assumes you have tables defined in the Hive metastore which you should have if you ran the earlier tutorials. Oracle Data Visualization Desktop ( here ) is a lightweight, single-file download tool to easily analyze data. Data Visualization Desktop can connect to a variety of data sources. In this tutorial, we will show you how you can use it to securely connect to BDCS-CE. We will connect via DV Desktop's support for ODBC and we will leverage an ODBC driver for Hive.

msg.data:
xtra tutorial: Working with Oracle Data Visualization Desktop and Hive

This tutorial was built for BDCS-CE version 17.3.5-20 as part of the New Data Lake User Journey: here. Questions and feedback about the tutorial: david.bayard@oracle.com

Note: This tutorial assumes you have tables defined in the Hive metastore which you should have if you ran the earlier tutorials.

Oracle Data Visualization Desktop ( here ) is a lightweight, single-file download tool to easily analyze data. Data Visualization Desktop can connect to a variety of data sources. In this tutorial, we will show you how you can use it to securely connect to BDCS-CE. We will connect via DV Desktop’s support for ODBC and we will leverage an ODBC driver for Hive.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# IMPORTANT: This Note is out-of-date

This note describes how to connect DVD to Hive via a third-party ODBC driver.  The advantage of this approach is that you do not need to reconfigure Hive on the BDCS-CE cluster.  This disadvantage is that DVD does not take advantage of Hive's full capabilities (as DVD limits its functionality to the bare minimum with ODBC connections).

Therefore, we no longer recommend this ODBC driver approach.

paragraphs.text: %md # Installing an ODBC driver for Hive DV Desktop can work with ODBC drivers. We will leverage this capability as it allows us to define some advanced parameters which will be needed to connect securely to our Hive instance in BDCS-CE. The first step is download and install an ODBC driver for Hive. + Navigate to here + Under Hortonworks Data Platform Add-ons, download the Windows (64bit) version of the latest Hortonworks ODBC Driver for Apache Hive ![HOdbcDownload](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/snap0012146.jpg "HODBC") + Run the downloaded MSI file to install it ![HOdbcinstall](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/HiveODBCinstall.gif "HODBC")

msg.data:
Installing an ODBC driver for Hive

DV Desktop can work with ODBC drivers. We will leverage this capability as it allows us to define some advanced parameters which will be needed to connect securely to our Hive instance in BDCS-CE. The first step is download and install an ODBC driver for Hive.

  • Navigate to here
  • Under Hortonworks Data Platform Add-ons, download the Windows (64bit) version of the latest Hortonworks ODBC Driver for Apache Hive
  • Run the downloaded MSI file to install it

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Configure the Hive ODBC Driver for BDCS-CE

+ Open up the Windows ODBC Data Sources (64 bit) tool.  The easiest way is to use the search icon and type in ODBC.
![ODBClaunch](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/snap0012147.jpg "HODBC")
+ Click on the System DSN tab
+ Click Add...
+ Choose the Hortonworks Hive ODBC driver
+ Enter a data source name (remember it for later as you will need it)
+ Enter the public IP address for your BDCS-CE instance master.  Hint: you can see this on the Oracle Cloud My Services page for your BDCS-CE instance
+ Enter 1080 for the port
+ Set the mechanism for authentication to User Name and Password
+ Set the User Name to admin username you use to sign-in to your BDCSCE cluster/notebook (the default username is bdcsce_admin)
+ Set the Password to the admin password you use to sign-in to your BDCSCE cluster
+ Choose HTTP for the the Thrift Transport
+ Click on HTTP Options and enter hs2service for the HTTP path
+ Click on SSL Options.  Check the box for Enable SSL, Allow Self-signed Server Certificate, and Allow Common Name Host Name Mismatch.
+ Click Test to make sure it works
+ Click OK
![ODBClaunch](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/HiveODBCconfig.gif "HODBC")

msg.data:
Configure the Hive ODBC Driver for BDCS-CE

  • Open up the Windows ODBC Data Sources (64 bit) tool. The easiest way is to use the search icon and type in ODBC.
  • Click on the System DSN tab
  • Click Add…
  • Choose the Hortonworks Hive ODBC driver
  • Enter a data source name (remember it for later as you will need it)
  • Enter the public IP address for your BDCS-CE instance master. Hint: you can see this on the Oracle Cloud My Services page for your BDCS-CE instance
  • Enter 1080 for the port
  • Set the mechanism for authentication to User Name and Password
  • Set the User Name to admin username you use to sign-in to your BDCSCE cluster/notebook (the default username is bdcsce_admin)
  • Set the Password to the admin password you use to sign-in to your BDCSCE cluster
  • Choose HTTP for the the Thrift Transport
  • Click on HTTP Options and enter hs2service for the HTTP path
  • Click on SSL Options. Check the box for Enable SSL, Allow Self-signed Server Certificate, and Allow Common Name Host Name Mismatch.
  • Click Test to make sure it works
  • Click OK

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Define a connection in DV Desktop for the Hive ODBC connection

+ Open up DV Desktop
+ Click on Data Sources
+ Click on Connection (Under Create)
+ Click on ODBC
+ Enter the Connection Name
+ Enter the DSN (be sure to use the exact Data Source Name you used when you configured the ODBC connection)
+ Set the Username to the admin username you use to sign-in to your BDCSCE cluster/notebook (the default username is bdcsce_admin)
+ Set the Password to the admin password you use to sign-in to your BDCSCE cluster

![DVDconnection](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/DVDconnection.gif "HODBC")

# Create a DV Desktop Data Source for your connection

+ Invoke the pop-up menu on your new Data Source and choose Create Data Source
+ Navigate through the database, tables, and columns to choose the elements you want to add.
+ Name the new data source and Add it
